text: you know I think what enabled me to
write the Memoir was something that
happens often in fiction you know when I
look back at the fiction I've published
and even the fiction I've finished but
haven't
published they're really sort of the
phoenixes that have risen From the Ashes
of what failed which is pretty normal
for I think a lot of people who write so
for me uh I was actually working on an
essay about baseball and um because
here's the deal I didn't know what
baseball was until really my 40s when my
kids got into it and um my oldest son
when he got into it uh I noticed as as I
got older the coaches became more
competitive and I didn't want my son to
have a drill instructor coach at age
eight so I volunteered to be a baseball
coach except I I quickly realized I
didn't know how to play baseball so I go
run Tommy run and some little kid be
pulling on my shoulder and say but coach
you can't run and I said oh you can't oh
I'm sorry so my point is what was
feeling the essay was the question how
did I miss baseball this game that I
really love now as a as a grownup you
know what was I doing instead of playing
ball and I you know I vaguely knew what
I was
doing
um but 550 Pages later I wrote what I
was really doing which was living in
poverty with our single mother and my
three siblings and and moving sometimes
two to three times a year for cheaper
rent and you know getting beat up a lot
and then snapping and and learning to
fight and then becoming a violent young
man until thank God I found writing
which kind of saved my
life you know I really wrestle with this
whole notion of what a modern man is and
I find it an endlessly fascinating
subject I think you have to talk about
this in a class way you know when I go
back to the neighborhoods I grew up in
and I go to the bars I used to hang out
in 30 years ago there are still guys
there my age in their early 50s who will
Who will get in a fight even though they
could lose a house or or get shot now
I'm not saying
that that workingclass people are more
violent by Nature I think that educated
upper class people get taught early that
that's not the way to express yourself
and I think there are more options that
keep you from expressing yourself that
way I have to admit that that as as much
as I hate violence and as much uh and I
hope and hopefully town is is is about
that I I I have always hated violence I
was a sensitive kid who got beat on and
I learned how to be become a perpetrator
but I always at a spiritual level knew
that what I was doing was negative that
said I do believe that part of being a
man is being able to defend your wife
from an assault and I think that that uh
most men would probably agree if pressed
and the truth is I haven't punched
anyone in 25 years but I still know how
to do it and and I'm glad I do and I
hope I never have to but that's one of
the things you know I write about in in
tow is that I think the biggest thing I
learned when I went from being um a
non-f fighter to a fighter is not how to
throw a punch uh anyone can learn that
on a heavy bag or or with an instructor
the biggest learning was what you have
to do to yourself spiritually and
psychologically to hurt another human
being and that whole notion of the
membrane I describe where this is
something I was semiconscious aware of
during my fighting years but it's really
inappropriate you know we just met it'd
be inappropriate for me to for me to
reach over and touch your cheek even you
know gently it's a violation of your
private space I don't know you well
enough it's inappropriate think how
inappropriate it is to ball your fist up
and punch someone in a face as hard as
you possibly can it is such a violation
of and when of sort of sort of this
membrane that's around all of us that
should be inviolet and sacred we should
all have this this barrier around us
that that no one can come into without
our permission when you look at
consensual sex between adults you know
we lower that barrier we say yes you can
come close and that's fine but in a
fight you have to violate that barrier
and to me that was the biggest piece of
learning psychologically is is you have
to learn to to violate that in order to
violate to break that membrane around
somebody you got to break that membrane
around yourself and in I experience I
had to break and keep breaking and keep
tearing my own compassion for another
human being my own sense of suffering
with someone else to really not care if
I hurt that person I was punching in the
face so back to the Dilemma of the
modern
man um I think the more educated and
sensitive and empathetic we get is all
good but I frankly think we need to keep
hold of that rep reptilian part of
ourselves that are that is not
reasonable and knows how to tear that
membrane if we have to and may we never
have to and by the way it's harder to
not fight than to
fight once you know how to do that
psychologically again it's much more of
a psychological stance in the world to
be a fighter than a non- fighter once
you're you're in that zone it's very
difficult not to reach for the gun the
metaphorical gun because it's harder to
be diplomatic and it's harder to resolve
conflict with speech and uh it's got me
it's gotten me thinking about nuclear
war and and weapons and it's easier to
press a button than to engage in fight
years of messy
diplomacy and and I just my my years as
a fist fighter informs that
thought
